coredata.dc:description: In-situ polymerized gel polymer electrolytes have been considered as the most promising alternative to liquid electrolyte owing to their high ionic conductivity, improved safety, simple and environmentally friendly manufacturing process, and good interfacial compatibility with electrodes. However, their poor mechanical properties are not able to prevent the Li dendrites growth in batteries. Inspired by the composite electrolytes, an asymmetrical gel electrolyte (A-PGCE) consisting of cellulose membrane-supported gel electrolyte and LLZTO-rich layer on one side is fabricated by a facile one-step in-situ polymerization method. The well-designed A-PGCE not only exhibits excellent properties such as superior flexibility, good thermal stability and wide electrochemical window (5.13 V), but also possesses high ionic conductivity (1.25 × 10-3 S cm−1) and Li+ transference number (0.57). Furthermore, the introduced LLZTO-rich layer demonstrates excellent ability in guiding uniform Li+ deposition and suppressing Li dendrite growth, which enables the symmetrical Li-Li cells with such electrolyte to run stably for over 1750 h at 0.1 mA cm−2 and 450 h at 0.2 mA cm−2. Benefiting from these advantages of A-PGCE, the assembled Li metal battery with high-voltage LiCoO2 (LCO) cathode shows high initial capacity of 157.6 mAh g−1 in the cutoff voltage of 4.3 V, and the capacity retention is 90.7% after 200 cycles at 0.2C, indicating a superior cyclic stability. The cleverly designed asymmetrical A-PGCE shows great potential in boosting the development of lithium metal batteries with high energy density and safety.

head.ce:title: A cleverly designed asymmetrical composite electrolyte via in-situ polymerization for high-performance, dendrite-free solid state lithium metal battery

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: In-situ polymerized gel polymer electrolytes have been considered as the most promising alternative to liquid electrolyte owing to their high ionic conductivity, improved safety, simple and environmentally friendly manufacturing process, and good interfacial compatibility with electrodes. However, their poor mechanical properties are not able to prevent the Li dendrites growth in batteries. Inspired by the composite electrolytes, an asymmetrical gel electrolyte (A-PGCE) consisting of cellulose membrane-supported gel electrolyte and LLZTO-rich layer on one side is fabricated by a facile one-step in-situ polymerization method. The well-designed A-PGCE not only exhibits excellent properties such as superior flexibility, good thermal stability and wide electrochemical window (5.13 V), but also possesses high ionic conductivity (1.25 × 10-3 S cm−1) and Li+ transference number (0.57). Furthermore, the introduced LLZTO-rich layer demonstrates excellent ability in guiding uniform Li+ deposition and suppressing Li dendrite growth, which enables the symmetrical Li-Li cells with such electrolyte to run stably for over 1750 h at 0.1 mA cm−2 and 450 h at 0.2 mA cm−2. Benefiting from these advantages of A-PGCE, the assembled Li metal battery with high-voltage LiCoO2 (LCO) cathode shows high initial capacity of 157.6 mAh g−1 in the cutoff voltage of 4.3 V, and the capacity retention is 90.7% after 200 cycles at 0.2C, indicating a superior cyclic stability. The cleverly designed asymmetrical A-PGCE shows great potential in boosting the development of lithium metal batteries with high energy density and safety.

ce:section.ce:para: Nowadays, rechargeable lithium batteries with higher safety and energy density are urgently needed by advanced electronics and new electrical vehicles.[1–3] Among them, solid-state lithium batteries have been recognized as the most promising candidate for the past few years because of their notably improved safety when compared with batteries using volatile and flammable liquid electrolyte.[4–8] More importantly, using solid state electrolytes can also boost the commercialization of lithium metal anode by reducing interfacial side reaction and suppressing uncontrolled Li dendrite growth in conventional liquid electrolyte, which significantly improves the energy density of energy storage device.[9–11]

Generally, solid state electrolytes that is the most important part of solid batteries can be classified into two main categories, inorganic solid electrolytes and polymer electrolytes, and they possess very different characteristics.[12–14] Inorganic solid electrolytes including oxides and sulfides usually have good stability and high ionic conductivity, but the intrinsic brittleness and the complex manufacturing greatly block their industrialization process.[15,16] Besides, despite of tremendous efforts, the thickness of inorganic solid electrolyte is still not satisfactory, and their inherent rigidity also results in poor interfacial contact between electrolytes and electrodes.[17–19] These fatal drawbacks would bring about slow kinetic reactions during charge and discharge, thus limiting their commercial applications in solid state batteries severely. In comparison, polymer-based electrolytes that include solid polymer electrolytes (SPEs) and gel polymer electrolytes (GPEs) hold wider promise for the commercial solid-state batteries owing to their appealing merits such as low cost, lightweight, excellent flexibility, easy processability and good interfacial contact with electrodes.[20–22]

In recent years, among all polymer-based electrolytes, GPEs that combine the merits of polymer and liquid plasticizer have attracted growing attention because the absorbed liquid plasticizer not only improves the ionic conductivity greatly, but also wets the electrodes well, thus reducing the interfacial resistance of batteries significantly.[23–26] However, this strategy with liquid plasticizer also brings new problems. The liquid component is mechanically weak and its embedding may destroy the crosslinked state of polymer, leading to a significant decrease in mechanical strength.[27,28] This means that the high ionic conductivity of GPEs actually comes at the expense of mechanical strength, and the poor mechanical property can’t efficiently prevent the growth and penetration of Li dendrites during long-term cycling of Li metal batteries. It is commonly believed that the composite electrolytes which consist of inorganic ceramic and polymer inherit advantages of both and can suppress Li dendrite growth effectively.[29–32] Inspired by this, introducing mechanically-robust inorganic electrolyte fillers into polymer matrix may be an effective strategy to enhance the weak mechanical strength of GPEs.[33] And among inorganic solid electrolytes, garnet type is considered as the most desired fillers because of its high ionic conductivity and good stability to Li anode.[17,34–36] But they are expensive for industrial production. Li and co-workers introduced Ga-LLZO nanoparticles to GPE matrix and the obtained composite electrolyte demonstrated superior ability in suppressing Li dendrites growth during cycling.[37]

In addition to improving the performance of polymer electrolyte by adjusting its composition rationally, developing advanced preparation technology can also accelerate the commercialization of solid-state batteries. Conventionally, most polymer electrolytes and composite electrolytes are prepared by a solution-casting method, and some GPEs may require an extra step to introduce plasticizers by soaking the dry membrane into liquid electrolyte. [38–40] During this process, toxic organic solvents such as acetonitrile and acetone are used to dissolve polymer and alkali salt and then removed by heating, which is not very environment-friendly. Also, the residual solvent in solid electrolyte may react with electrodes, causing the performance deterioration in batteries. Therefore, finding a facile and environment-friendly method to prepare polymer-based electrolytes is of great urgency. In recent years, numerous studies have turned attention to in-situ polymerization technique which transforms liquid precursor to solid electrolyte directly by cross-linking of polymer monomer under special conditions.[41–44] This technique not only avoids the evaporation of polluting and toxic organic solvents, but also reduces the interfacial resistance between electrolyte and electrodes further by injecting liquid precursor into battery directly during assembly process.[37,45,46] Besides, the in-situ crosslinking of polymer is also beneficial to improve the mechanical strength of polymer electrolyte.[47,48]

Based on the above analysis, developing solid state electrolyte with simplified preparation process and superior performance is very important for the industrial technologies of solid-state batteries, and the in-situ polymerized GPEs reinforced with mechanically-robust inorganic electrolyte fillers maybe the breakthrough. Poly(ethylene glycol) diacrylate (PEGDA) which belongs to polyacrylates has been regarded as an ideal monomer for fabricating in-situ polymerized electrolyte owing to its superior crosslinking ability.[16,49] However, even though the electrochemical window of PEGDA-based electrolytes was reported over 4.5 V, they were rarely used in batteries with high-voltage LCO cathode in recent years.[50–52] And the reason for this is still not clear. In this work, we introduced a small amount of Li6.5La3Zr1.5Ta0.5O12 nanoparticles (LLZTO) to PEGDA-based GPE and prepared a novel asymmetrical composite electrolyte (A-PGCE) with a LLZTO-rich layer on one side via in-situ thermal polymerization. Here, a flexible cellulose membrane was introduced to enrich the LLZTO nanoparticles and provide a self-supporting skeleton for the liquid precursor to avoid the direct contact between two electrodes. The prepared A-PGCE exhibits superior properties such as flexibility, good thermal stability, wide electrochemical windows, high ionic conductivity and high Li+ transference number. The comparison of electrochemical properties with other asymmetrical gel composite electrolytes reported is shown in Table S1. Moreover, our experimental results prove that the designed A-PGCE electrolyte can guide the uniform deposition of Li+ and inhibit the Li dendrite growth compared with gel polymer electrolyte. The asymmetrical electrolyte was also successfully applied in high-voltage LCO/Li batteries, and the LCO/Li batteries also exhibit excellent electrochemical performance. This is almost the best electrochemical performance reported in LCO/Li batteries with PEGDA-based polymer electrolyte in recent years. So the prepared A-PGCE electrolyte in our work shows promise for being used in the next-generation solid-state lithium metal batteries.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Preparation of A-PGCE and PGPE electrolyte
ce:section.ce:para: The A-PGCE was fabricated by a facile in-situ polymerization method with polymer monomer (poly(ethylene glycol) diacrylate, PEGDA) and thermal initiator of 2,2′-Azobis(2-methylpropionitrile) (AIBN, Aladdin). First, PEGDA (Mn = 600, Aladdin) and lithium difluoro(oxalate)borate (LiDFOB, DoDoChem) were dissolved in a mixture of ethylene carbonate (EC) and dimethyl carbonate (DMC) (1:1 by volume, DoDoChem). Then 10 wt% LLZTO nanoparticles were added to form a white and homogeneous solution by magnetic stirring for several hours, and the SEM image of LLZTO powder is shown in Figure S1. After adding a certain amount of AIBN as initiator, the obtained mixture of about 30 μL was dripped on the dry cellulose membrane (d = 19 mm) placed on the glass plate, then another glass plate was placed on top to help the liquid precursor spread evenly over the surface of the membrane, thus a LLZTO-rich layer would form on the top of the cellulose membrane because of its enrichment effect. The mass ratio of PEGDA, LiDFOB, EC/DMC and AIBN was 20:10:100:0.3. Finally, the electrolyte precursor was completely polymerized by heating at 70 °C for 2 h, and then the asymmetrical A-PGCE electrolyte was obtained. For comparison, the PEGDA-based gel polymer electrolyte (PGPE) was prepared by the same method but without addition of LLZTO nanoparticles.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Preparation of LCO cathode and LCO/electrolyte/Li cell
ce:section.ce:para: Firstly, LCO powder, carbon nanotubes (CNTs) and poly(vinylidene fluoride) (PVDF) were mixed evenly at a mass ratio of 8:1:1 by grinding first. And then the mixed powder was added in 1-methyl-2-pyrrolidinone (NMP, Aladdin) and stirred for 6 h to get a homogeneous slurry. Subsequently, the cathode slurry was cast on Al foil and followed by heating at 80 °C for 12 h in vacuum to remove the solvent completely. The mass loading of the LCO cathode is about 1.2 mg cm−2. After that, the precursor solution of A-PGCE was dripped on the cellulose membrane (d = 19 mm) that was placed on the LCO cathode (d = 15 mm) in a CR2025 coin-type cell, and then a piece of Li metal was placed on top as anode. After completely sealing, the cell went through the same polymerization process by heating at 70 °C for 2 h. The LCO/PGPE/Li cell was assembled by the same process. To be clear, all types of cells for testing were assembled using this similar method of direct polymerization on different electrodes.

The bonding structure of electrolyte before and after polymerization was studied by Fourier transform infrared spectrometer (FTIR, Thermo IS50). The Hitachi SU8010 scanning electron microscopy (SEM) with X-ray energy spectrometer was used to characterize the morphologies of electrolytes and Li anodes. The X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded using a Rigaku D/max-2250PC diffractometer (Cu Kα) in the range of 10° to 80° to investigate the phases of cellulose membrane and electrolytes. Thermo-gravimetric analysis was conducted on a Thermo SDT-Q600 thermal analyser under N2 atmosphere to explore the thermal stability of electrolytes, and this test was performed from room temperature to 800 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C min−1. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was employed to investigate the surface components of Li anodes after cycling and it was carried out on a Thermo Scientifc K-Alpha + X-ray photoelectron spectrometer with Al Kα radiation.

A Princeton multi-channel electrochemical workstation was used to obtain the electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) of different-type cells, and the results were recorded in 10-2 ∼ 106 Hz with an AC amplitude of 10 mV. Blocking cells with two stainless-steel electrodes (SS) were assembled to obtain the ionic conductivity (σ) of electrolytes. Based on the bulk resistance (R) of electrolyte obtained from Nyquist curve, the ionic conductivity (σ) can be calculated using equation as follows:
σ = L/ RA (1)

where L and A stand for the thickness of electrolyte and the area of SS electrode, respectively. The Li+ transference number (tLi+ ) of electrolytes was measured by combination of EIS analysis and DC polarization with symmetrical Li/electrolyte/Li cells. And the Bruce-Vincent equation for calculation is as follows:

where the applied potential ΔV is 10 mV, R0 and Rs represent interfacial resistance before and after polarization, I0 and Is refer to the initial and stable current, respectively [53]. The electrochemical stability of electrolytes was determined by linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) with SS/electrolyte/Li cells, and this test was carried out on a CHI660E electrochemical workstation at a scanning rate of 0.1 mV s−1 from open-circuit voltage to 6 V. To record the long-term galvanostatic charge–discharge behavior of LCO/electrolyte/Li cells and symmetrical Li/electrolyte/Li at room temperature, Land CT3001A battery testing system was used. And the voltage range of LCO/ Li cells for testing is from 3.0 to 4.3 V.

Fig. 1 a presents the preparation schematic of A-PGCE electrolyte. The well-mixed liquid precursor with LLZTO nanoparticles was dripped on cellulose membrane first. The photograph and morphology of the pristine cellulose membrane are shown in Figure S2, it exhibits good flexibility and possesses a dense network structure formed by interwoven fibers. Therefore, after adding liquid precursor, the LLZTO nanoparticles can be enriched on one side of the cellulose membrane while the liquid component can pass through and be well absorbed by membrane under gravity. After polymerization, an asymmetrical solid electrolyte with a LLZTO-rich layer on top can be obtained, as shown in the magnified part in Fig. 1a.

The optical photos in Fig. 1b display the solidifying evolution from liquid precursor to solid state electrolyte. PEGDA with low molecular weight is liquid, and the white precursor of A-PGCE gradually becomes solid as the unsaturated C = C bonds are opened and polymerized under the attack of free radical produced by thermal initiator.[41] During this process, the introduced liquid plasticizer (EC/DMC-LiDFOB) is also encapsulated inside the electrolyte to provide fast Li+ transport pathway. Different from the semitransparent PGPE electrolyte (Figure S3a), the A-PGCE membrane with LLZTO nanoparticles presents a milk white color and there is no any visible defect (Fig. 1c), demonstrating the uniform distribution of LLZTO particles in top layer. Besides, as can be seen from Fig. 1c, the A-PGCE membrane also exhibits superior flexibility, it can be bent and folded but still presents an undamaged surface after unfolding. And this can be attributed to the introduced flexible cellulose membrane because it not only provides a self-supporting skeleton for the liquid precursor but also helps to overcome the intrinsic brittleness of polymerized PEGDA,[28] thus a flexible electrolyte can be obtained.

SEM characterization was used to illustrate the overall structure of the A-PGCE more clearly. Fig. 2 a shows the cross-sectional SEM image of A-PGCE electrolyte, and the asymmetrical structure with a LLZTO-rich layer on one side can be clearly observed, which demonstrates the successful fabrication of the designed asymmetrical electrolyte via the proposed smart and facile method. Benefiting from the supporting effect of the thin cellulose membrane, the overall thickness of the A-PGCE is as thin as 35 µm, and the magnified figure inset shows that the formed LLZTO-rich layer on one side is roughly 7 µm. Under the shear forces of scissor for preparing sample, the harder LLZTO-rich layer with polymerized PEGDA is slightly detached from the cellulose membrane layer. Furthermore, the vacuum process before observation leads to the evaporation of liquid plasticizer, coupled with the differential mechanical properties of LLZTO-rich layer and polymerized PEGDA, which may further aggravate the delamination of the sample too. Fig. 2b and 2c compare the surface morphology of both A-PGCE and PGPE electrolytes. The A-PGCE membrane presents a flat surface on LLZTO-rich layer side and no obvious agglomeration can be observed, which proves the uniform distribution of LLZTO particles in this layer. And the EDS mapping results in Figure S4 demonstrate its asymmetrical structure and uniformity further. For PGPE electrolyte in Fig. 2c, it displays a generally flat surface but some fibers belonging to the cellulose membrane can be also observed.

FTIR was carried out to confirm the polymerization of PEGDA oligomers in liquid precursor under heating. As can be seen from the FTIR spectra in Fig. 2d, the characteristic peak of C = C stretching vibration at 1637 cm−1 that belongs to PEGDA oligomers almost disappears after thermal cured, demonstrating a successful and complete polymerization under designed experimental conditions.[27,54] The corresponding 1H NMR spectra of PEGDA precursor and polymer after polymerization are shown in Figure S5. After polymerization, the CH2 = CHR group (5.95–6.4 ppm) almost disappears, indicating that the polymerization ratio of PEGDA under designed experimental condition is almost 100%.

The phases of electrolytes were examined by XRD. Fig. 2e shows the XRD patterns of A-PGCE and PGPE electrolytes. Obviously, the peaks of LLZTO in A-PGCE are consistent with the JCPDS card (PDF#01–080-6076),[53] indicating that the typical cubic phase of LLZTO remains unchanged during the mixing and polymerization process. In addition, other obvious peaks observed in both electrolytes can be assigned to the cellulose membrane, as proved by its XRD patterns in Figure S6. It is worth mentioning that both PGPE and A-PGCE electrolytes show a broader diffraction peak ranging from 10° to 30° compared with cellulose membrane, which can be ascribed to the polymerized PEGDA with very low crystallinity. This result indicates that the introduced liquid plasticizer can decrease the crystallinity of polymer effectively, and the large amorphous area is beneficial to facilitate the Li+ migration in electrolyte.[23] To prove the good mechanical properties of electrolyte prepared, tensile test was conducted. As shown in Figure S7, the tensile strength of A-PGCE electrolyte is about 18.9 MPa while for PGPE electrolyte this value is only 14.3 MPa. Based on the slope of fitting line, the Young’s modulus of A-PGCE electrolyte can be calculated as 467.5 MPa while it is 376.6 MPa for PGPE electrolyte. Therefore, the A-PGCE electrolyte demonstrates better mechanical properties than PGPE electrolyte, which can be ascribed to the LLZTO nanoparticles introduced. The improved mechanical properties may have a positive effect on suppressing Li dendrites.

To investigate the thermal stability of electrolytes and the influence of LLZTO-rich layer, TG analysis was performed. Fig. 2f displays the TG curves of electrolytes and liquid plasticizer. For A-PGCE and PGPE electrolyte, two main stages of weight loss can be observed. The first stage below 180 ˚C corresponds to the rapid evaporation and decomposition of organic solvent, especially DMC with an extremely low boiling point of about 90 ˚C.[27] After that, other components such as PEGDA and LiDFOB began to decompose, which corresponds to the slow weight loss of the second stage after 180 ˚C. And the decomposition of cellulose membrane starts at about 300 ˚C, as proved by its TG curve in Figure S8. The magnified part inset clearly shows that the weight loss of PGPE and A-PGCE electrolyte at the same temperature is much smaller than that of liquid plasticizer below 150 ˚C, which proves the effective encapsulation of liquid electrolyte in polymer network. Also, the A-PGCE electrolyte shows a slower weight loss than PGPE electrolyte and the weight loss at 127 ˚C is about 10 wt%, indicating that the A-PGCE has a better thermal stability than PGPE. Maybe the introduced dense LLZTO-rich layer is able to preserve the organic solvents in electrolyte and slow their evaporation. Therefore, both the encapsulation of liquid electrolyte and the LLZTO-rich layer contribute to improve the safety performance of A-PGCE electrolyte. And this characteristic may lead to a broader application of A-PGCE electrolyte.

For the application of electrolytes, ionic conductivity is a vital electrochemical property. Fig. 3 a shows the EIS profiles of PGPE and A-PGCE electrolytes at room temperature. The intercept on the Z’ axis represents the bulk resistance (R) of electrolytes. Benefiting from the absorbed liquid plasticizer, the R values of PGPE and A-PGCE are 1.426 and 1.582 Ω, respectively. Therefore, the ionic conductivity of PGPE and A-PGCE electrolytes can be calculated as 1.27 × 10-3 and 1.25 × 10-3 S cm−1, respectively. This result indicates that the introduction of a LLZTO-rich layer doesn’t influence the ionic conductivity significantly. The high ionic conductivity of both electrolytes can be ascribed to two aspects below. On the one hand, it is well-known that liquid electrolyte usually possesses a much higher ionic conductivity than polymer matrix and LLZTO, which is close to 10 mS cm−1. So it is the abundant liquid component immobilized in polymer that provides the main transport pathway for Li+. On the other hand, the PEGDA matrix shows a low crystallinity, as proved by XRD patterns in Fig. 2e. The large amorphous area in electrolytes also contributes to improve Li+ conductivity. In terms of the role of LLZTO filler, many previous works thought that the introduced ceramics could improve the ionic conductivity by decreasing the crystallinity of polymer and providing fast Li+ transport pathway at interface by percolating interfacial effect in composite electrolyte.[55,56] However, the XRD patterns of A-PGCE in Fig. 2e don’t show a broader diffraction peak than that of PGPE, which implies that the LLZTO particles has little effects on decreasing crystallinity as the added liquid plasticizer is enough to destroy the crystalline region of PEGDA completely. Conversely, the introduction of a LLZTO-rich layer may result in a decrease in liquid component. Therefore, A-PGCE electrolyte exhibits a slightly decreased ionic conductivity compared with PGPE electrolyte, which matches well with the results of the experimental measured ionic conductivity.

To investigate the activation energy (Ea) of ion transference in electrolytes, the fitting Arrhenius plots of PGPE and A-PGCE electrolyte are shown in Fig. 3b. Based on the slop of the fitting line between log σ and T−1, the Ea of PGPE and A-PGCE can be calculated as 0.120 and 0.103 eV, respectively. The decreased Ea in A-PGCE may be attributed to the introduction of LLZTO particles. It is generally believed that the introduced ceramic fillers can immobilize partial anions in electrolyte by Lewis acid–base interaction,[57] so the electrostatic interaction between Li+ and anion during migration can be reduced, which results in a smaller Ea value. For electrolytes, the relationship between ionic conductivity (σ) and activation energy (Ea ) obeys the Nernst-Einstein equation as follows:[58]
(3)

where n and q represent the concentration and charge of mobile ions in electrolytes respectively, and D0 is a constant. Therefore, both factors including concentration of mobile ions (n) and activation energy (Ea ) influence the ionic conductivity (σ) greatly. For A-PGCE electrolyte, the concentration of mobile ions is lower because of the decreased liquid component while the ion migration is easier owing to the lower activation energy (Ea). So the A-PGCE electrolyte exhibits a slightly lower ionic conductivity than PGPE. Even though, the A-PGCE electrolyte still possesses a high ionic conductivity that can meet the requirement of batteries.

To study the effect of LLZTO particles on electrochemical stability, Li/electrolyte/SS cells were assembled, and the LLZTO-rich layer was toward Li electrode. Fig. 3c presents the LSV curves of cells assembled with PGPE and A-PGCE electrolyte. It can be observed that the electrochemical stability of A-PGCE can reach above 5.13 V while the PGPE begins to decompose at about 4.71 V (versus Li+/Li), where supposing that the current density of 5 μA cm−2 means the beginning of decomposition as proposed by previous report.[59] The notably enhanced electrochemical stability of A-PGCE electrolyte can be attributed to the introduced LLZTO filler as itself possesses high oxidative stability. Besides, some researches proposed that ceramic fillers could also improve the decomposition potential of anions and polymers by Lewis acid-base interactions and dipole–dipole interactions, respectively.[57,60] And the wide electrochemical window makes it suitable for diverse cathodes, especially for those working at high voltage such as LCO.

For such a dual-ion electrolyte system, the Li+ transference number (tLi+) is another key parameter. It is defined as the ratio of Li+ to all mobile ions, in other words, representing the effective Li+ transportation in electrolyte. Under the same electric field, Li ions and anions (DFOB-) move simultaneously but toward opposite electrodes, and Li ions can be consumed by depositing or intercalating while anions are easy to accumulate at the electrolyte/electrode interface, which results in a large concentration polarization in batteries. So improving tLi+ contributes to accelerate the Li+ transport and decrease the polarization in batteries. Fig. 3d displays the testing result of A-PGCE electrolyte. According to the Bruce-Vincent equation mentioned in experimental section, the tLi+ value of A-PGCE electrolyte can be calculated as 0.57. While for the PGPE electrolyte, this value is only 0.35 (Figure S9), which is close to that of liquid electrolyte. The higher Li+ transference number of A-PGCE can be attributed to the introduced LLZTO particles because they can immobilize partial anions by Lewis acid-base interaction.[60,61] Besides, it is well-known that the LLZTO itself is a kind of single-ion conductor (tLi+ =1).

To investigate the stability of prepared electrolytes against Li anode, the lithium stripping/plating behavior with symmetrical Li/electrolyte/Li cells was monitored. The symmetrical Li/A-PGCE/Li cells were assembled using the same method of fabricating Li/A-PGCE/Li cell mentioned in experimental part but replacing the LCO cathode with another Li piece. And the area capacity of charge and discharge for all tests was fixed at 0.1 mAh cm−2. Fig. 4 a presents the rate performance of Li/electrolyte/Li cells from 0.1 mA cm−2 to 1 mA cm−2, and the charge and discharge are performed 20 cycles at each current density. Clearly, the Li/PGPE/Li cell shows an obvious sudden drop in voltage during the cycling of 1 mA cm−2 and still presents an extremely low overpotential of almost zero at 0.1 mA cm−2, which means that the Li/PGPE/Li cell may have suffered from a short circuit. However, the Li/A-PGCE/Li cell exhibits smaller overpotential than Li/PGPE/Li cell at each current density, and demonstrates superior reversibility when the current density returns to 0.1 mA cm−2. More importantly, no short circuit appears during the cycling of Li/A-PGCE/Li cell. The long-term cycling of Li-Li cells at 0.1 mA cm−2 is shown in Fig. 4b. For the cell with PGPE electrolyte, the overpotential increases rapidly with cycling, indicating an extremely unstable electrolyte/Li interface caused by Li dendrite growth and dead Li accumulation. Finally, a sudden voltage drop occurs at about 294 h, which implies that the uncontrollable Li dendrites puncture the electrolyte and result in a short circuit. However, as demonstrated in Fig. 4b, the cell with A-PGCE electrolyte can be cycled for over 1750 h without short circuit, and it just shows a slightly increased polarization. During such long testing time, various factors such as unstable room temperature and the inevitable reaction between highly reductive Li and liquid plasticizer are responsible for the increased polarization. When the current density increases to 0.2 mA cm−2, the result is similar. The Li/A-PGCE/Li cell can run stably for over 450 h while the Li/PGPE/Li cell suffers from a short circuit at about 226 h. Therefore, it can be concluded that the asymmetrical A-PGCE electrolyte with LLZTO-rich layer exhibits excellent stability against Li anode and enables long-term cycling of batteries compared with PGPE electrolyte. As aforementioned, A-PGCE electrolyte has high Li+ conductivity and notably enhanced Li+ transference number, which enables fast Li+ migration and small concentration polarization in batteries, so the Li/A-PGCE/Li cells present smaller overpotential than Li/PGPE/Li cells. Furthermore, the high Li+ transference number also enables it to guide the uniform deposition of Li+ by promoting the limiting current density of dendrite nucleation and delaying nucleation time, thus preventing the formation and growth of Li dendrites effectively.[29,60,62] More importantly, the A-PGCE electrolyte reinforced with mechanically-robust inorganic electrolyte is not easily punctured by Li dendrites. All of these factors mentioned above help to form a stable Li/electrolyte interface during long-term cycling in Li/A-PGCE/Li cell.

To further prove the point proposed, the morphologies of Li anodes and the resistance of Li/electrolyte/Li cells during cycling at 0.2 mA cm−2 are provided. The uncycled Li anode is shown in Figure S10. For the Li/ PGPE/Li cells in Fig. 5 b, the surface of Li anode starts to get a little bit rough after 50 cycles due to the formation of Li dendrite and dead Li. And the rough surface would result in uneven distribution of current, thereby further causing nonuniform deposition of Li+. As the cycle increases, more isolated dead Li accumulates and Li dendrites continue to grow uncontrollably. As a result, the Li anode gets rougher after 100 cycles and even presents a totally broken surface after 200 cycles. Finally, the PGCE electrolyte is punctured by Li dendrites, causing the failure of Li-Li cell because of a short circuit. In contrast, as shown in Fig. 5a, the Li anodes disassembled from Li/A-PGCE/Li cells present smooth and compact surface at different cycles, and no obvious defects or dendrites can be observed, indicating the stable and uniform deposition of Li+ during the repeated stripping/plating process. Fig. 5c-d display the resistances of Li/A-PGCE/Li and Li/PGPE/Li cells before and after 50, 100, 200 cycles at 0.2 mA cm−2. The resistance of Li/PGPE/Li cell increases from 121 Ω to 270 Ω after 200 cycles, which is consistent with the significantly increased polarization of voltage profiles. And the accumulated dead Li and severe Li dendrites at Li/electrolyte interface shown in Fig. 5b are mainly responsible for the increased internal resistance and polarization in batteries. In contrast, the Li/A-PGCE/Li cell shows a small resistance change of about 40 Ω before and after 200 cycles. Based on the above analysis, the designed A-PGCE electrolyte exhibits superior stability against Li during long-term cycling and the introduced LLZTO-rich layer plays an important role in inhibiting growth of Li dendrites.

To further evaluate the electrochemical performance of electrolytes prepared, LCO/electrolyte/Li full batteries were assembled and then tested. Usually, conventional solid-state batteries assembled by stacking method show high interfacial resistance due to the solid–solid contact between layers, and the addition of electrolyte to cathode for constructing Li+ transport network greatly limits the improvement of energy density in batteries. To address these issues, the cells used in this work were fabricated via an in-situ thermal polymerization method as described in experimental section. The liquid precursor was injected into the cells and then polymerized between cathode and anode directly. During this process, the liquid can seep into the porous LCO cathode and then forms well-connected Li+ conducting network after thermal polymerization. Fig. 6 a presents the detailed structure of LCO/A-GPCE/Li cell, in which the LLZTO-rich layer is set on the Li side and the soft polymer is toward cathode. It is worth mentioning that the in-situ method almost eliminates the visible physical interface between electrodes and electrolyte. Both the good Li+ conducting network in cathode and the intimate interface would be beneficial to facilitate kinetic reaction in batteries.

Fig. 6b presents the rate performance of LCO/A-PGCE/Li and LCO/PGPE/Li cells from 0.2C to 2C. Apparently, the LCO/A-PGCE/Li cell exhibits better rate performance than LCO/PGPE/Li cell. Under the cutoff voltage of 4.3 V, the LCO/A-PGCE/Li cell exhibits remarkably high discharge capacities of 159 mAh g−1, 149.5 mAh g−1, 131.6 mAh g−1 and 94.7 mAh g−1 at 0.2C, 0.5C, 1C and 2C (1C = 140 mA g−1), respectively. When the current density returns to 0.2C, the capacity can recover to 155.1 mAh g−1, which demonstrates superior reversibility. However, the cell with PGPE electrolyte just delivers a reversible capacity of 131 mAh g−1, which is much lower than its initial capacity of 149.3 mAh g−1 at 0.2C, and the subsequent discharge capacity also shows a tendency to decay with cycling. Actually, the high Li+ transference number makes A-PGCE possess higher effective Li+ conductivity than PGPE, which enables fast reaction kinetics and high utilization of active material in batteries. Therefore, the LCO/A-PGCE/Li cell exhibits higher capacity than LCO/PGPE/Li cell, especially at high current density. The long-term cycling performance of the LCO/electrolyte/Li cells at 0.2C in 3.0–4.3 V is provided in Fig. 6c. As can be seen, the initial discharge capacity of LCO/A-PGCE/Li cell is about 157.6 mAh g−1, and the capacity retention can reach 90.7% after 200 cycles, revealing a remarkable cycling stability. While for the cell with PGPE electrolyte, the capacity decays rapidly with cycling and even falls to almost zero after 100 cycles. Also, LCO/A-PGCE/Li cell displays higher coulombic efficiency (CE) than LCO/PGPE/Li cell. Fig. 6d and 6e present the corresponding charge and discharge curves of both cells during cycling at 0.2C. It can be seen that the LCO/A-PGCE/Li cell exhibits stable polarization during cycling but the polarization of LCO/PGPE/Li cell increases with cycles significantly. Therefore, the full cell with A-PGCE electrolyte exhibit notably enhanced electrochemical performance in term of higher capacity and better cycling stability.

To study the surface morphology and chemical composition of cycled Li anodes dissembled from different LCO/electrolyte/Li cells, SEM and XPS were employed, respectively. As shown in Fig. 7 a, the Li anode dissembled from LCO/A-PGCE/Li cell presents a smooth surface after 200 cycles, indicating the uniform deposition of Li+ on the surface. However, the Li anode cycled with PGPE electrolyte possesses an extremely rough surface, and a lot of Li dendrites and dead Li can be clearly observed in Fig. 7d. This result also demonstrates that the A-PGCE prepared exhibits superior ability in suppressing Li dendrites and guiding uniform Li deposition. Fig. 7b-c and 7e-f present the corresponding XPS results of different Li anodes. For C 1 s spectra of Li anode cycled with A-PGCE electrolyte (Fig. 7b), the peak at 284.8 eV can be assigned to C–C/C–H signal, and the other two peaks at 286.4 eV and 288.8 eV correspond to C-O and C=O respectively, which may originate from the decomposition products of carbonate plasticizer such as ROCO2- and ROC-.[17,63] The O 1 s spectra in Fig. 7c also proves the existence of C=O (531.1 eV) and C-O (532.3 eV) signal. Similarly, the C 1 s spectra of Li anode cycled with PGPE electrolyte also has three peaks located at 284.8 eV (C–C/C–H), 286.4 eV (C-O) and 288.8 eV (C=O). Nevertheless, compared with Li anode with A-PGCE electrolyte, it shows a much stronger intensity of C-O signal, which can be ascribed to the increased decomposition products. The rough and broken surface may be responsible for this result because the increased area makes carbonate solvents react with highly reactive Li more violently. Therefore, these results mentioned above also prove the more stable Li/electrolyte interface in LCO/A-PGCE/Li cell. And the intimate and stable electrodes/electrolyte interfaces play an important role in improving electrochemical performance of LCO/A-PGCE/Li cell. Furthermore, the wide electrochemical window of A-PGCE also contributes to the excellent stability of LCO/A-PGCE/Li cell during cycling. While in LCO/PGPE/Li cell, the irreversible accumulation of dead Li and continuous growth of Li dendrites at the interface bring about large polarization, thus resulting in decreased capacity and low CE in batteries. Besides, LiDFOB may also have a positive effect on enhancing electrochemical performance because it has been reported to stabilize the high voltage cathode such as NCM by decomposing to construct stable cathode/electrolyte interface.[64] Therefore, the cleverly designed asymmetrical electrolyte with a LLZTO-rich layer is beneficial to improve the electrochemical stability of LCO/Li cells, including high capacity and good cyclic stability. This compositing strategy can be applied to other inorganic electrolyte and polymer system too.

To further investigate the practical applicability of A-PGCE electrolyte in batteries, the pouch-type LCO/A-PGCE/Li cell was assembled. As shown in Fig. 7g, the pouch cell exhibits a small resistance of about 255 Ω, which proves that the in-situ polymerization strategy has a significant effect on reducing the interfacial resistance in battery. Fig. 7h-m present the LCO/A-PGCE/Li pouch cell under different states. As can be seen in Fig. 7i, the pouch cell is able to light up the LED lamp under normal condition. After that, large mechanical deformations such as bending and folding are applied, and LED lamp remains lit (Fig. 7j-k), demonstrating superior flexibility and robust mechanical affordability of assembled pouch cell. Even under harsh condition of being cut a half or piece, it can still light up the LED lamp successively (Fig. 7m) without internal short circuit, proving the good safety of pouch cell. Therefore, it can be concluded that the cell with A-PGCE electrolyte can work under large mechanical deformations or damaged state, which shows great promise for practical application in flexible electronic devices.

In summary, we prepared an asymmetrical composite electrolyte consisting of cellulose membrane-supported gel electrolyte and LLZTO-rich layer on one side by a smart design which takes advantages of the enrichment effect of cellulose membrane on particles and the subsequent in-situ polymerization process. The obtained A-PGCE membrane shows superior flexibility and good thermal stability. In addition, it also possesses wide electrochemical window (5.13 V), high ionic conductivity (1.25 × 10-3 S cm−1) and high Li+ transference number (0.57). Furthermore, the A-PGCE electrolyte with mechanically-robust LLZTO-rich layer demonstrates excellent ability in guiding uniform Li+ deposition and suppressing Li dendrites growth. In full cell with such asymmetrical electrolyte, the soft cellulose membrane-supported gel electrolyte can form intimate contact with cathode, and the LLZTO-rich layer toward Li anode contributes to stabilize the electrolyte/Li interface and prevent the batteries from short-circuiting. Benefiting from these superior properties, the high-voltage LCO/A-PGCE/Li cells display excellent electrochemical performance including high capacity and good cyclic stability. This study provides a new sight for driving the development of lithium metal batteries with high energy density and high safety.
